metadata.author: G. S. Tutorial
metadata.description: Class 9 Science - Chapter 13: Why Do We Fall Ill

question.text: (CBSE 2023) Which disease is caused by a virus?
question.explanation: Common cold caused by rhinovirus. TB: bacteria (Mycobacterium), Typhoid: bacteria (Salmonella), Cholera: bacteria (Vibrio).

question.text: (SEBA 2023) The chemical substances that kill or stop growth of pathogens are called:
question.explanation: Antibiotics target bacteria (e.g., penicillin). Not effective against viruses. Vaccines prevent, antibodies fight infection.
Malaria spreads via mosquito (communicable). Diabetes, cancer, arthritis are non-communicable (don't spread).
BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) prevents TB. Given at birth in many countries including India.

question.text: (CBSE 2021) Which disease is caused by protozoa?
question.explanation: Malaria: Plasmodium protozoa. Typhoid/cholera: bacteria. Tetanus: bacteria (Clostridium).

question.text: (SEBA 2021) Diseases that last for short period are called:
question.explanation: Acute: short duration (cold, diarrhea). Chronic: long lasting (TB, diabetes, cancer).

question.text: (CBSE 2020) Which vitamin deficiency causes night blindness?
question.explanation: Vitamin A deficiency → night blindness, xerophthalmia. Sources: carrots, spinach, milk, eggs.
AIDS: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome caused by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus). Attacks immune system.

question.text: (CBSE 2019) Which is NOT a bacterial disease?
question.explanation: Influenza (flu) caused by virus. TB: Mycobacterium, Typhoid: Salmonella, Cholera: Vibrio bacteria.

question.text: (SEBA 2019) The disease that spreads through contaminated water is:
question.explanation: Cholera: water-borne (fecal contamination). TB: airborne, Malaria: mosquito, AIDS: blood/body fluids.
Aedes aegypti mosquito transmits dengue virus. Anopheles: malaria. Housefly: typhoid, cholera. Rat flea: plague.
Iodine needed for thyroid hormone. Deficiency → goiter (enlarged thyroid). Prevented by iodized salt.
WHO definition: complete physical, mental, social well-being, not merely absence of disease.

question.text: Which disease is caused by vitamin C deficiency?
question.explanation: Scurvy: bleeding gums, weakness. Vitamin C sources: citrus fruits, amla, green vegetables.
B-lymphocytes produce antibodies against specific antigens. Part of immune response.
TB spreads through air (droplets from coughing). Cholera/typhoid: water/food. Malaria: mosquito.
Penicillin discovered by Alexander Fleming (1928) from Penicillium fungus. First antibiotic.
Pathogens: disease-causing microbes (bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, worms).
Congenital: present from birth (genetic/inherited or during pregnancy). Hemophilia: genetic bleeding disorder.

question.text: The full form of AIDS is:
question.explanation: Caused by HIV which attacks CD4 T-cells, weakening immune system.
Iron needed for hemoglobin. Anemia: fatigue, weakness. Sources: leafy vegetables, meat, jaggery.
DPT: Diphtheria, Pertussis (whooping cough), Tetanus. Given in childhood immunization program.
Dengue symptoms: high fever, severe joint/muscle pain (breakbone), rash. Caused by dengue virus (4 serotypes).

question.text: Which is NOT a viral disease?
question.explanation: Typhoid: bacterial (Salmonella). Polio, rabies, smallpox: viral. Smallpox eradicated globally (1980).
Rickets: soft, weak bones in children. Vitamin D helps calcium absorption. Sources: sunlight, fish, egg yolk.

question.text: The process of developing immunity without falling ill is called:
question.explanation: Vaccination introduces weakened/killed pathogen → body produces antibodies → memory cells provide future protection.

question.text: Which disease spreads through sexual contact?
question.explanation: STDs: Syphilis, gonorrhea, AIDS. Spread through sexual contact. Others: malaria (mosquito), typhoid (contaminated food/water), TB (air).
Wuchereria bancrofti (filarial worm) transmitted by mosquito → blocks lymph vessels → swelling (lymphedema).
ORS: sugar + salt + water, treats dehydration from diarrhea. Recommended by WHO.

question.text: Which disease is eradicated from world?
question.explanation: Smallpox eradicated in 1980 through vaccination. Polio nearly eradicated (few cases remain).
Female Anopheles feeds on blood (needs for eggs), transmits Plasmodium. Males feed on plant nectar.
Ringworm: fungal infection of skin (not caused by worm). Athlete's foot also fungal.

question.text: Pulse Polio program aims to eradicate:
question.explanation: Pulse Polio: mass immunization in India started 1995. Polio virus causes paralysis, mainly in children.
Beri-beri: nerve, heart issues. Thiamine sources: whole grains, pulses, meat.
Antiseptics: on living tissue (skin, wounds) e.g., Dettol, Savlon. Disinfectants: on non-living objects.
Jaundice: yellow skin/eyes due to bilirubin buildup. Caused by liver dysfunction (hepatitis, obstruction).
Hepatitis A spreads through contaminated water/food. TB: airborne, Malaria: mosquito, Influenza: airborne droplets.

question.text: The disease caused by Niacin deficiency is:
question.option: Rickets Pellagra: diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia. Niacin (Vitamin B3) sources: meat, peanuts, whole grains.

question.text: Immunity present from birth is called:
question.option: Passive immunity Innate: present from birth (skin, mucous membranes, WBCs). Acquired: develops after exposure/vaccination.

question.text: Which disease is transmitted by housefly?
question.option: Rabies Houseflies carry pathogens from feces/filth to food → typhoid, cholera, dysentery.

question.text: The time between infection and appearance of symptoms is called:
question.option: Symptomatic period Incubation period: pathogen multiplies, no symptoms. Varies by disease: common cold 1-3 days, rabies weeks-months.
